trans-unit.source: How to Create a PowerShell Tab in Windows PowerShell ISE
trans-unit.target: How to Create a PowerShell Tab in Windows PowerShell ISE

trans-unit.source: powershell,cmdlet
trans-unit.target: powershell,cmdlet

trans-unit.source: How to Create a PowerShell Tab in Windows PowerShell ISE
trans-unit.target: How to Create a PowerShell Tab in Windows PowerShell ISE

trans-unit.source: Tabs in the Windows PowerShell® Integrated Scripting Environment (ISE) allow you to simultaneously create and use several execution environments within the same application.
trans-unit.target: Tabs in the Windows PowerShell® Integrated Scripting Environment (ISE) allow you to simultaneously create and use several execution environments within the same application.

trans-unit.source: Each PowerShell tab corresponds to a separate execution environment or session.
trans-unit.target: Each PowerShell tab corresponds to a separate execution environment or session.

trans-unit.source: Variables, functions, and aliases that you create in one tab do not carry over to another.
trans-unit.target: Variables, functions, and aliases that you create in one tab do not carry over to another.

trans-unit.source: They are different Windows PowerShell sessions.
trans-unit.target: They are different Windows PowerShell sessions.

trans-unit.source: Use the following steps to open or close a tab in Windows PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: Use the following steps to open or close a tab in Windows PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: To rename a tab, set the [DisplayName](The-PowerShellTab-Object.md#Displayname) property on the Windows PowerShell Tab scripting object.
trans-unit.target: To rename a tab, set the [DisplayName](The-PowerShellTab-Object.md#Displayname) property on the Windows PowerShell Tab scripting object.

trans-unit.source: To create and use a new PowerShell Tab
trans-unit.target: To create and use a new PowerShell Tab

trans-unit.source: On the **File** menu, click **New PowerShell Tab**.
trans-unit.target: On the **File** menu, click **New PowerShell Tab**.

trans-unit.source: The new PowerShell tab always opens as the active window.
trans-unit.target: The new PowerShell tab always opens as the active window.

trans-unit.source: PowerShell tabs are incrementally numbered in the order that they are opened.
trans-unit.target: PowerShell tabs are incrementally numbered in the order that they are opened.

trans-unit.source: Each tab is associated with its own Windows PowerShell console window.
trans-unit.target: Each tab is associated with its own Windows PowerShell console window.

trans-unit.source: You can have up to 32 PowerShell tabs with their own session open at a time (this is limited to 8 on Windows PowerShell ISE 2.0.)
trans-unit.target: You can have up to 32 PowerShell tabs with their own session open at a time (this is limited to 8 on Windows PowerShell ISE 2.0.)

trans-unit.source: Note that clicking the **New** or **Open** icons on the toolbar does not create a new tab with a separate session.
trans-unit.target: Note that clicking the **New** or **Open** icons on the toolbar does not create a new tab with a separate session.

trans-unit.source: Instead, those buttons open a new or existing script file on the currently active tab with a session.
trans-unit.target: Instead, those buttons open a new or existing script file on the currently active tab with a session.

trans-unit.source: You can have multiple script files open with each tab and session.
trans-unit.target: You can have multiple script files open with each tab and session.

trans-unit.source: The script tabs for a session only appear below the session tabs when the associated session is active.
trans-unit.target: The script tabs for a session only appear below the session tabs when the associated session is active.

trans-unit.source: To make a PowerShell tab active, click the tab.
trans-unit.target: To make a PowerShell tab active, click the tab.

trans-unit.source: To select from all PowerShell tabs that are open, on the **View** menu, click the PowerShell tab you want to use.
trans-unit.target: To select from all PowerShell tabs that are open, on the **View** menu, click the PowerShell tab you want to use.

trans-unit.source: To create and use a new Remote PowerShell tab
trans-unit.target: To create and use a new Remote PowerShell tab

trans-unit.source: On the **File** menu, click **New Remote PowerShell Tab** to establish a session on a remote computer.
trans-unit.target: On the **File** menu, click **New Remote PowerShell Tab** to establish a session on a remote computer.

trans-unit.source: A dialog box appears and prompts you to enter details required to establish the remote connection.
trans-unit.target: A dialog box appears and prompts you to enter details required to establish the remote connection.

trans-unit.source: The remote tab functions just like a local PowerShell tab, but the commands and scripts are run on the remote computer.
trans-unit.target: The remote tab functions just like a local PowerShell tab, but the commands and scripts are run on the remote computer.

trans-unit.source: To close a PowerShell Tab
trans-unit.target: To close a PowerShell Tab

trans-unit.source: To close a tab, you can use any of the following techniques:
trans-unit.target: To close a tab, you can use any of the following techniques:

trans-unit.source: Click the tab that you want to close.
trans-unit.target: Click the tab that you want to close.

trans-unit.source: On the **File** menu, click **Close PowerShell Tab**, or click the Close button (**X**) on an active tab to close the tab.
trans-unit.target: On the **File** menu, click **Close PowerShell Tab**, or click the Close button (**X**) on an active tab to close the tab.

trans-unit.source: If you have unsaved files open in the PowerShell tab that you are closing, you are prompted to save or discard them.
trans-unit.target: If you have unsaved files open in the PowerShell tab that you are closing, you are prompted to save or discard them.

trans-unit.source: For more information about how to save a script, see [How to Save a Script](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/162f594d-efd3-4234-9960-45e56e6eadc8).
trans-unit.target: For more information about how to save a script, see [How to Save a Script](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/162f594d-efd3-4234-9960-45e56e6eadc8).

trans-unit.target: See Also
